roleset.name: the great indefinable

example.name: transitive, NP
example.text: Mike remained in trance ; there was much to grok

example.name: transitive, SBar
example.text: Mike grokked this was true , but grokked that there was more to it .

example.name: intransitive
example.text: Now that he knew himself to be self , he was free to grok ever closer to his brothers , merge without let .

roleset.note: GROK-V NOTES: This word was invented by Robert Heinlein in 'Stranger in a StrangeLand' to denote an experience alien to the human condition. As such,it is largely undefined--indeed, most of the story is devoted to ahuman learning what 'grokking' is all about. In later usage, 'grok'has been shifted to mean 'to understand (fully)' which, while takingthe same argument structure (except not the intransitive), loses muchof the magic of the original. (from grok.01-v)
